topics.name: Headlines
topics.shortDescription: News you'll definitely be interested in
topics.longDescription: The latest events and announcements from the world of Android development.

topics.name: UI
topics.longDescription:
Stay up to date on Material Design, Navigation, Text, Paging, Compose, Accessibility (a11y), Internationalization (i18n), Localization (l10n), Animations, Large Screens, Widgets and much more!

To get Compose specific news, make sure you also follow the Compose topic.

topics.name: Compose
topics.longDescription: All the latest and greatest news on Jetpack Compose - Android‚Äôs modern toolkit for building native user interfaces.

topics.name: Architecture
topics.longDescription: Stay up-to-date with Android architecture best practices including scalability and modularization.

topics.name: Android Studio & Tools
topics.longDescription: The latest news on Android development tools, including Android Studio, Gradle, device emulators, debugging tools and more.

topics.name: Testing
topics.longDescription: The latest news on testing, including unit and UI testing, and continuous integration.

topics.name: Performance
topics.longDescription: Up-to-date content on optimizing your app performance, including profiling, tracing and jank avoidance.

topics.name: New APIs & Libraries
topics.longDescription: Stay up-to-date with new APIs & library releases, including Jetpack.

topics.name: Data Storage
topics.longDescription: Everything to do with data storage, including Room and DataStore.

topics.name: Kotlin
topics.longDescription: New language features and guidance for getting the best out of Kotlin on Android.

topics.name: Privacy & Security
topics.longDescription: The latest news on security best practices, APIs and libraries.

topics.name: Publishing & Distribution
topics.longDescription: Everything to do with publishing and distributing your app, including Google Play.

topics.name: Platform & Releases
topics.longDescription: Stay up-to-date with the latest Android releases and features.

topics.name: Accessibility
topics.longDescription: The latest news on accessibility features and services, helping you to improve your app's usability, particularly for users with disabilities.

topics.name: Android Auto
topics.longDescription: The latest news on Android Automotive OS and Android Auto.

topics.name: Android TV
topics.longDescription: Stay up-to-date on everything to do with building apps for Android TV.

topics.name: Games
topics.longDescription: The latest news on Android game development.

topics.name: Camera & Media
topics.longDescription: The latest news on capturing and playing media on Android, including the Camera and Media APIs.

topics.name: Wear OS
topics.longDescription: The latest news on app development for Wear OS.

newsresources.title: Android Dev Summit ‚Äô22: Coming to you, online and around the world! ‚õ∞Ô∏è
newsresources.content: Android Dev Summit is back, so join us online or in person ‚Äî for the first time since 2019 ‚Äî at locations around the world. We‚Äôll be sharing the sessions live on YouTube in three tracks spread across three weeks.

newsresources.title: The new Google Pixel Watch is here  ‚Äî start building for Wear OS! ‚åö
newsresources.content: We launched the Google Pixel Watch, powered by Wear OS 3.5, at the Made by Google event ‚Äî the perfect device to showcase apps built with Compose for Wear OS. With Compose for Wear OS, the Tiles Material library, and the tools in Android Studio Dolphin, it‚Äôs now simpler and more efficient than ever to make apps for WearOS.

newsresources.title: Listen to our major Text to Speech upgrades for 64 bit devices üí¨
newsresources.content: An upgrade to Speech Services by Google is rolling out to 64-bit Android devices via Google Play over the next few weeks, providing clearer, more natural voices. All 421 voices in 67 languages are being upgraded with a new voice model and synthesizer. The post includes more on this update, including demonstrations of some voice upgrades, along with guidance on how to use text to speech in your projects.

newsresources.title: MAD Skills Compose: Powerful Toolkit
newsresources.content: Learn about the powerful toolkit of UI components that ship with Compose enabling you to build rich UIs and interactions.

newsresources.title: MAD Skills Compose: Accelerate development with tooling
newsresources.content: Learn how to accelerate your Compose development process with a dive into Android Studio tooling support, including live templates, gutter icons for drawables and colors, composable preview functions, multipreview, preview on device, live edits of literals, and the Layout Inspector.

newsresources.title: Deep Links Crash Course: Part 3 - Troubleshooting
newsresources.content: In part 3 of the Deep Links Crash Course you'll learn how to diagnose and debug common issues with deep links using command line tools and the Android Debug Bridge (ADB).

newsresources.title: Deep Links Crash Course: Part 4 - Deep links for your business
newsresources.content: Part 4 of the Deep Links Crash Course explores Deep links for your business, covering the importance and benefits of implementing deep links for your app, your users, and your business, including success stories and how App Links provide an optimal experience for users.

newsresources.title: Migrating the AOSP QuickSearchBox App to Kotlin
newsresources.content: This article includes the methodology used in the migration to Kotlin, how manual changes were addressed, and what the impact to APK size and build speed was.

newsresources.title: Prepare your Android Project for Android Gradle plugin 8.0 API changes
newsresources.content: How to prepare your Android Project for Android Gradle plugin 8.0 API changes; this article specifically addresses migrating from the Transform APIs ‚Äî which slow down builds and will be removed in 8.0 ‚Äî to the Artifacts API and Instrumentation API.

newsresources.title: Optimize for Android (Go edition) : Lessons from Google apps Part 2
newsresources.content: Part two of the Optimize for Android Go : Lessons from Google apps blog series, covering strategies Google apps used to improve startup latency and optimize app size ‚Äî things that will improve the user experience for any app.

newsresources.title: Helping users discover apps for all their devices from their phone
newsresources.content: Changes in Google Play are helping users discover apps for all their devices from their phone, including homepages for non-phone devices, a device search filter, and the ability to remotely install an app to another device.

newsresources.title: Deep Links Crash Course : Part 3 Troubleshooting Your Deep Links
newsresources.content: The Deep Links Crash Course continues with Summers writing an article on troubleshooting deep links. He goes over common issues that can occur with deep links and how to solve them.

newsresources.title: Jetpack Compose Composition Tracing
newsresources.content: Ben covered Compose Composition Tracing, a new feature that allows showing Jetpack Compose composable functions in the Android Studio Flamingo system trace profiler. This feature gives you the low intrusiveness from system tracing, with method tracing levels of detail in composition. This is great for checking your Compose app‚Äôs performance and working out why your app may not be performing as you expect. Learn more about this feature in the post!

newsresources.title: Android Studio: Dolphin is available
newsresources.content: Android Studio Dolphin is here! In this post, Takeshi goes over the three key themes: Jetpack Compose, Wear OS, and development productivity. Exciting features include the Compose Animation Inspector, the Wear OS Emulator Pairing Assistant, and Gradle managed virtual devices. Learn about all the new features in the blog post or the video!

newsresources.title: Mad Skills: Compose
newsresources.content: Chris started a brand new MAD Skills series on Compose. This series is a great place to start to learn how to think and start building apps with Compose.

newsresources.title: Introducing Compose Camp
newsresources.content: We launched Compose Camp, a series of in-person and virtual sessions where you can learn how to build Android apps with Jetpack Compose alongside your peers. Compose Camp has two tracks: the beginner track caters to complete Android beginners including people that have no coding experience, and the experienced track is for Android developers who want to learn how to migrate to Compose and stop using XML.

newsresources.title: Privacy Sandbox developer preview 5 üîê
newsresources.content: The Privacy Sandbox aims to develop new technologies that improve user privacy and enable effective, personalized advertising experiences for mobile apps. Developer Preview 5 was released, this version is a major milestone that will become the foundation for upcoming Privacy Sandbox Beta releases. Please keep giving us your feedback! See what‚Äôs changed in the blog post.

newsresources.title: Guide to app modularization üß©
newsresources.content: The team just released new guidance on modularization. Guidance on this topic has been one of the top community requests and here it is! The guide is split into two parts. The overview page gives you a high level, theoretical overview of the matter and its benefits. The common modularization patterns page dives deep into practical examples in the context of modern Android architecture. Take a look at the guide announcement blog post to learn more about this.

newsresources.title: Build an offline-first app
newsresources.content: If you need to make your app work offline, we got you covered. The new Build an offline-first app guide helps you design your app to properly handle reads and writes, and deal with synchronization and conflict resolution in a device with no Internet connectivity.

newsresources.title: State holders and UI state page
newsresources.content: Another new guide is the State holders and UI state page in the UI layer docs. Not everything needs to be present in ViewModel classes. This page goes through the different types of state holders you can find in the UI layer and what their responsibilities are.

newsresources.title: Architecture pathway
newsresources.content: If you want to learn all about Architecture and be up-to-date with our current best practices, check out the Architecture pathway, that got updated with all the videos of the Architecture MAD Skills series we produced early this year and the new docs.

newsresources.title: Mad Skills: Performance ‚ö°Ô∏è
newsresources.content: Ben wrote this blog post that contains a summary of all the videos on MAD Skills: Performance! Don't miss it out!

newsresources.title: AndroidX releases üöÄ
newsresources.content: Since the previous episode, there are some AndroidX releases worth highlighting.Core and core-ktx made it to 1.9.0 stable. This version improves compatibility with Android 13 adding parity between the accessibility framework and compat APIs, and some other additions. Other releases include new in beta Car app 1.3, and new in alpha Navigation 2.6 and Test Ui Automator 2.3.

newsresources.title: Precise Improvements: How TikTok Enhanced its Video Social Experience on Android
newsresources.content: The Developer Relations team wrote about how TikTok Enhanced its Video Social Experience on Android. They were able to significantly improve their overall performance by following Android‚Äôs performance guidance, and employing their deep understanding of development tools such as Android Gradle Plugin and Jetpack libraries. Read more here!

newsresources.title: The deep links crash course, Part 1: Introduction to deep links
newsresources.content: Sabs started a crash course series about deep links. The first part is an introduction to deep links with a blog post and a video. Get to know what a deep link is, go from URIs to app links, and more!

newsresources.title: Experimenting with Jetpack Glance
newsresources.content: Marcel wrote about experimenting with Jetpack Glance that covers a standalone experimental repository to supplement Jetpack Glance with tools that are commonly required for development but not yet available. At the moment, it includes a composable to display RemoteViews inside your app (enabling Live Edit), a debug tool to view and interact with AppWidget snapshots embedded inside the app, and a Material3 Scaffold for AppWidgets.

newsresources.title: Jetpack Compose: Debugging Recomposition
newsresources.content: Ben Trengove wrote about Debugging recomposition in Compose. Check it out because it also contains a screencast of Ben fixing a performance issue in Jetsnack, a Compose sample. For this, Ben also uses the layout inspector in Android Studio where you can see the recomposition and skip counts of composable functions.

newsresources.title: Optimize for Android (Go edition): Lessons from Google apps - Part 1
newsresources.content: Nikariha started another blog post series about optimizing for Android Go edition. The first part introduces Android Go edition, why you‚Äôd want to build for it, and some best practices based on experience building the Gboard and Camera from Google apps.

newsresources.title: ADB Podcast Episodesüéô: Episode 188 - Android 13
newsresources.content: In Episode 188: Android 13, Chet, Romain, and Tor talk about some of their favorite new features and changes of the new version of Android, both for users and developers.

newsresources.title: Cross device SDK Developer Preview üì±‚ÜîÔ∏èüì±
newsresources.content: We launched the Cross device SDK for Android developer preview, which allows you to build rich multi-device experiences, abstracting away the intricacies involved with working with device discovery, authentication, and connection protocols.

newsresources.title: CameraX 1.2 is now in Beta
newsresources.content: CameraX version 1.2 is now in Beta. It introduces a zero shutter lag capture mode along with MlKitAnalyzer, an implementation of ImageAnalysis.Analyzer that handles much of the ML Kit setup for you. MlKitAnalyzer works with both cameraController and cameraProvider workflows and can even handle coordinate transformations between ML Kit output and your PreviewView. Zero shutter lag greatly reduces image capture lag on supported devices by using a circular buffer of captures to get the frame closest to the actual press of the shutter button.

newsresources.title: Build Tiles fast with the WearOS Material Tiles Library ‚åö
newsresources.content: Tiles are one of the most used surfaces on Wear OS, providing users glanceable access to the information and actions they need to get things done quickly. We launched the Tiles Material library allowing you to use pre-built Material components such as Button, Chip, CompactChip, TitleChip, CircularProgressIndicator, and Text along with layouts such as PrimaryLayout, EdgeContentLayout, MultiButtonLayout, and MultiSlotLayout to create tiles that embrace the latest Material design for Wear OS. Together with the Tiles Design Kit, they help you to easily follow the Tiles Design Guidelines.

newsresources.title: New deep links monitor in Play Console üîó
newsresources.content: Deep links allow you to get your users directly to in-app content by accepting traffic from external sources, including the web. Since answering basic questions like ‚Äúis this URL deep-linked?‚Äù or ‚Äúwhy is this deep link not working?‚Äù can be difficult to answer, many apps have partial, broken, or no deep links configured. To make it easier for you to keep your deep links in good shape, we‚Äôve introduced a new, dedicated Play Console page that gives you a quick but comprehensive snapshot of your current setup along with tooling to help you identify and troubleshoot issues at a glance.

newsresources.title: Celebrating 5 years of Kotlin on Android üéâ
newsresources.content: Five years ago Android announced official support for the interoperable, mature, production-ready, and open source Kotlin programming language. Since then, JetBrains and Google have been collaborating around the development of Kotlin, and the Kotlin Foundation was co-founded by the two companies; JetBrains developing both the language and tooling has given Kotlin outstanding IDE support. We put together some posts and videos to celebrate the journey and elaborate the milestones of Kotlin on Android with many of the people that helped to make it happen.

newsresources.title: Mad Skills: Performance üèéÔ∏èüí®
newsresources.content:
The MAD Skills series on Performance continued with a blog post from 
Ben and a video from Tom√°≈° that covers how to use the Macrobenchmark library along with UIAutomator to help generate Baseline Profiles for you. Baseline Profiles help your app to start and run faster by optimizing critical code paths ahead of time, allowing for a smoother user experience.

newsresources.title: AndroidX releases üöÄ
newsresources.content: In AndroidX, the Wear Compose Version 1.0.1 release fixed a logic bug in ScalingLazyColumn. As mentioned before, we released Wear Tiles Version 1.1. Webkit Version 1.5 added setAlgorithmicDarkeningAllowed, and added support for setting an allow-list of URLs for the configured proxy.

newsresources.title: A story of App Excellence, featuring Tik Tok
newsresources.content: Over in video, we covered how TikTok used Android tools to improve app startup and make the user experience more seamless, and how it impacted app usage and Play Store ratings.

newsresources.title: Design high-quality apps for kids
newsresources.content: We introduced the Google Play Academy course around designing kids‚Äô apps, ensuring that they‚Äôre fun, usable, and appropriate for their target age group. The course covers the framework for rating kids apps on Google Play that teachers across the US use, so you can understand what they‚Äôre looking for to help your app stand out.

newsresources.title: MAD about Media
newsresources.content: Avish, our summer Android DevRel Engineer intern, discussed modern approaches to creating Android media apps leveraging experience in converting the Universal Android Media Player (UAMP) media playback sample app to Compose, updating it to use modern libraries such as Media3.

newsresources.title: Top Tips for Adopting Android‚Äôs Notification Permission
newsresources.content: Terence covered tips to improve your app‚Äôs user experience with notifications before targeting Android 13, as well as how to test your app‚Äôs integration with the permission without flashing different OS versions onto your device.

newsresources.title: Jetpack Compose Accompanist ‚Äî An FAQ.
newsresources.content: Ben wrote a FAQ on the Jetpack Compose Accompanist, a labs-like environment for new Compose APIs. Accompanist is used to help fill known gaps in the Compose toolkit, experiment with new APIs and to gather insight into the development experience of building a Compose library. The goal of Accompanist is to eventually upstream libraries into the official toolkit. (at which point they will be deprecated and removed from Accompanist) Current libraries in Accompanist include support for Flow Layouts, Pager, Navigation Transitions, and Swipe Refresh.

newsresources.title: Introducing the MAD Skills series on Performance
newsresources.content: It‚Äôs time for another series of MAD Skills on Performance! Performance spans every aspect of Android development, and as part of Modern Android Development we‚Äôre aiming to make it more approachable and user-friendly. We have also found direct correlations between improved app performance, user satisfaction and business metrics.

newsresources.title: MAD Skills: Important Performance Metrics
newsresources.content: Before you begin to work with performance effectively, we recommend you make yourself familiar with key performance metrics. By understanding what metrics you should look at, you will make inspecting, improving and monitoring performance easier.

newsresources.title: MAD Skills: Inspecting Performance
newsresources.content: This MAD Skills article on inspecting performance introduces you to tools and methods that help when your code‚Äôs performance. When you inspect performance you make sure that what‚Äôs happening in your app aligns with what you expect to happen.

newsresources.title: Consuming flows safely in Jetpack Compose
newsresources.content: Collecting flows in a lifecycle-aware manner is the recommended way to collect flows on Android. If you‚Äôre building an Android app with Jetpack Compose, use the collectAsStateWithLifecycle API to collect flows in a lifecycle-aware manner from your UI.

newsresources.title: Brushing up on Compose Text coloring
newsresources.content: Alejandra Stamato‚Äôs last article covered compose brush text coloring, and this week she taught us how to take it a step further and add animation to brush text coloring. She covers using the animation APIs in conjunction with the Brush APIs, demonstrating these with a candy cane shimmer effect and a back-and-forth shimmer effect.

newsresources.title: Final Android 13 Beta update, official release is next!
newsresources.content: We‚Äôre just a few weeks away from the official release of Android 13! Meanwhile, we published the last Beta for your testing and development. We reached Platform Stability at Beta 3, so all app-facing surfaces are final, including SDK and NDK APIs, app-facing system behaviors, and restrictions on non-SDK interfaces. With these and the latest fixes and optimizations, Beta 4 gives you everything you need to complete your testing.

newsresources.title: 10 years of Google Play
newsresources.content: In 2012, the team opened the (digital) doors of Google Play. A decade later, more than 2.5 billion people in over 190 countries use Google Play every month to discover apps, games and digital content. And more than 2 million developers work with us to build their businesses and reach people around the globe! Congratulations to the Google Play team for this huge milestone.

newsresources.title: Android Basics with Compose Unit 3 available
newsresources.content: The Unit 3 of Android Basics with Compose course is available already! Unit 3 covers how to build apps that display a list of data and how to make your apps more beautiful with Material Design.

newsresources.title: Jetpack Compose 1.2 is now stable
newsresources.content: This release contains new features like downloadable fonts, lazy grids, and improvements for tablets and Chrome OS with better focus, mouse, and input handling.

newsresources.title: Compose for Wear OS is now 1.0
newsresources.content: Compose for Wear OS makes building apps for Wear OS easier, faster, and more intuitive by following the declarative approach and offering powerful Kotlin syntax. Moving forward, Compose for Wear OS is our recommended approach for building user interfaces for Wear OS apps.

newsresources.title: AndroidX releases üöÄ
newsresources.content: Jetpack Compose 1.2, Compose for Wear OS 1.0, Core splashscreen v1.0, and Profile Installer v1.2 went stable. In RC, you can find AppCompat v1.5, Compose Compiler v1.3 (that brings support to Kotlin version 1.7.10), Emoji2 v1.2, and ShareTarget v1.2. Lastly, Wear Tiles v1.1 reached its first beta version!

newsresources.title: Make your app large screen ready
newsresources.content: Learn how to get started with large screen support and why it is so important. Accurately handling orientation changes, aspect ratios, and adaptive layouts may seem challenging, but with new large screen experiences in mind, multiple form factors bring new possibilities to your users.

newsresources.title: Get familiar with Wear OS 3 (without a physical device)
newsresources.content: You don‚Äôt need a physical device to test your Wear apps. Read this article to take a brief look at unique UI surfaces on Wear OS, create a Wear emulator and explore it from a user perspective.

newsresources.title: Jetpack Compose Interop: Using Compose in a RecyclerView
newsresources.content: What versions of Compose and RecyclerView do you need to use to get the best performance? In addition, you‚Äôll understand how the interop works under the hood.

newsresources.title: Brushing up on Compose Text coloring
newsresources.content: A very colorful blog post about how to work with Brush API together with TextStyle to achieve complex text coloring like giving a gradient to your text in a simple way.

newsresources.title: Animating brush Text coloring in Compose üñåÔ∏è
newsresources.content: Learn how to animate gradients in your text using the Brush API and Compose animations. Go check them out, I can‚Äôt stop looking at those animations now!

newsresources.title: Prepare your app to support predictive back gestures
newsresources.content: Predictive back gestures is a feature that will be available in future versions of Android. However, to give you more time to adopt it, we made it available in the developer options of Android 13 Beta 4. Read the blog post for details on how to try out the new gesture and support it in your apps. Spoiler alert: it‚Äôs straightforward for most apps!

newsresources.title: ADB Podcast Episodesüéô187: System UI: A Retrospective
newsresources.content: In this episode Tor and Chet meet Dan Sandler and Adam Cohen from the SystemUI team. They dip into a bit of history, talking about where things were at when they joined the team, and how things have developed in the many years since. They also talk about how to expose (or not) gestures and features in a UI system.

newsresources.title: Developer-Powered CTS (CTS-D) üß™
newsresources.content: The Compatibility Test Suite (CTS) is a key part of the Android Compatibility Program that helps to ensure that devices provide a stable, consistent environment for your apps. To enhance CTS, we are adding a new test suite called CTS-D that is built and run by developers like you. You can build and contribute test cases to CTS-D to help catch pain points that you are seeing in the field ‚Äî places where device behavior doesn‚Äôt match the Android public APIs and the Android Compatibility Definition Document (CDD).

newsresources.title: Independent versioning of Jetpack Compose libraries ‚úíÔ∏è
newsresources.content: We announced that the various Jetpack Compose libraries will move to independent versioning schemes, making it easier to incrementally upgrade your application and stay up-to-date with the latest Compose features.

newsresources.title: Notes from Google Play: making Play work for everyone ‚ñ∂Ô∏è
newsresources.content: In the latest edition of Notes from Google Play, we touched on the Play Integrity API, the Data Safety section, the Privacy Sandbox on Android, and the newly-launched Google Play SDK Index, which provides data and insights about over 100 of the most widely used commercial SDKs. We covered new subscription capabilities that allow you to create multiple base plans and offers for each subscription, as well as the option to lower prices starting at the equivalent of 5 US cents to adapt to local purchasing power.

newsresources.title: Dark theme testing in Pre-Launch Report üï∂Ô∏è
newsresources.content: After you upload and publish a test Android App Bundle to Google Play, we install it on a set of Android devices, launch and crawl your app for several minutes, and compile your results into the pre-launch report. We‚Äôve introduced a new test in the Pre-Launch Report that runs accessibility checks on a device switched to dark theme; this can detect color contrast issues that make it difficult to differentiate text and icons from a background.

newsresources.title: Performance tips to achieve App Excellence
newsresources.content: The Performance tips to achieve App Excellence video covered five app performance issues along with the tools that Android Studio and Google Play Console provide to help you diagnose and troubleshoot them.

newsresources.title: Making Sense of Intent Filters in Android 13
newsresources.content:
Before Android 13, when an app registered an exported component in its manifest and added an <intent-filter>, the component could be started by any explicit intent ‚Äî even those that do not match the intent filter. In some circumstances this can allow other apps to trigger internal-only functionality.

This behavior has been updated in Android 13. Now intents that specify actions and originate from external apps are delivered to an exported component if and only if the intent matches its declared <intent-filter> elements.

newsresources.title: Customizing AnimatedContent in Jetpack Compose üåü
newsresources.content: Rebecca covers using AnimatedContent to transition between different composables with a smoother and more custom transition effect. Even the default behavior of AnimatedContent can make a big difference to the look and feel of your app, without much effort.

newsresources.title: Jetpack Compose Stability Explained
newsresources.content: Ben does a detailed exploration of how Compose determines the stability of each parameter of your composables to see what can be skipped during recomposition, including using compiler reports to determine what stability is being inferred about your classes.

newsresources.title: Migrating to the new coroutines 1.6 test APIs
newsresources.content:
kotlinx.coroutines 1.6 introduces a set of new testing APIs, and the previous testing APIs are now deprecated.
 
Marton talked about how we‚Äôve migrated some of our own samples to the new APIs, covering a bunch of the necessary work for most Android projects.

newsresources.title: Android 13 beta 3
newsresources.content: We released the third beta of Android 13! Android 13 has been built on our core themes of privacy and security, developer productivity, and large screen support. ‚Äã‚ÄãBeta 3 takes Android 13 to Platform Stability, which means that the developer APIs and all app-facing behaviors are now final; you can confidently develop and release your updates. Read all about it in the post!

newsresources.title: Google Play @ Google I/O - 3 updates you need to know
newsresources.content: In this video and blog post, Phalene tells us about the top three things to know about Google Play from Google I/O. These include updates on custom store listings, introducing more developers to the LiveOps beta, and new subscription capabilities. Learn more about these three topics in the video or blog post!

newsresources.title: Privacy Sandbox Developer Preview 3
newsresources.content: The Privacy Sandbox on Android aims to develop new solutions that preserve user privacy while enabling effective, personalized advertising experiences for apps. Now it is in Developer Preview 3, which adds APIs and resources for conversion measurement and remarketing use cases; this allows you to begin testing and evaluating impact on all key APIs for Privacy Sandbox on Android.

newsresources.title: ADB Podcast Episodesüéô186: Live Edit
newsresources.content: In this episode, we talk with Alan and Esteban from Android Studio about the new "Live Edit" feature recently launched at Google I/O in the Electric Eel canary build. We dive into the technology -- how it works, what the technical challenges are, and its current state.

newsresources.title: AndroidX releases
newsresources.content: Let‚Äôs take a look at what‚Äôs been up with AndroidX releases since the last episode of Now in Android. We have a few new features that are stable including Wear Watchface, Games-Activity, Benchmark, and Annotation

newsresources.title: Google I/O recaps ‚è± - Modern Android Development!
newsresources.content:
Our goal is to make developing beautiful and engaging Android apps as fast and easy as possible. We want to take on the complex parts of building apps so that you can focus on your app‚Äôs features and deliver high quality experiences to your users.

We call this approach Modern Android Development (or MAD for short!) and deliver it through a suite of tools, libraries and guidance. At Google I/O we announced a number of updates and additions to our MAD offerings; here‚Äôs a recap of the three largest announcements.

newsresources.title: Google I/O recaps ‚è± - Form factors!
newsresources.content: With close to half a billion cars, TVs, watches and laptops running on Android, it is more important than ever for apps to work seamlessly across every device. This year at I/O, we renewed our focus on form factors and announced major updates for Wear OS and Large Screens. To help you get to the bottom of what‚Äôs new, here are the three things you need to know about Form Factors at Google I/O

newsresources.title: Google I/O recaps ‚è± - Android Privacy, Platform & Security!
newsresources.content: Amidst the whirlwind of content at Google I/O, we shared huge announcements involving privacy, security, and the Android platform. Read on for the details, and don‚Äôt forget to watch the topic playlist on YouTube.

newsresources.title: Spot your UI jank using CPU profiler in Android Studio
newsresources.content: Takeshi wrote about spotting your UI jank using the CPU profiler in Android Studio. The article goes through a step by step walkthrough about how to use the new jank detection UI in Android Studio Chipmunk including how to record a trace, and how to inspect janky frames.

newsresources.title: Custom Canvas Animations in Jetpack Compose ‚ú®
newsresources.content: Rebecca Franks wrote about custom Canvas animations in Jetpack Compose. Using the Animatable states and some side-effects, you‚Äôll be able to achieve custom animations as you were able to do with ValueAnimator in the View system.

newsresources.title: Implementing Dynamic Color: Lessons from the Chrome team
newsresources.content: If you‚Äôre interested in Material You dynamic color, Rebecca Gutteridge talks about how the Chrome team implemented it and the things they kept in mind such as accessibility, custom colors, incognito, and more. It also comes with a really helpful list of recommendations from the designers and developers of the team.

newsresources.title: ViewModel: One-off event antipatterns
newsresources.content: We‚Äôre very opinionated about what to do with ViewModel events in our UI events Architecture guidance, and this blog post explains why the alternatives to our recommendation might bring higher engineering costs to developers and a worse user experience.

newsresources.title: Diving Into Compose ‚Äî Lessons Learned While Building Maps Compose
newsresources.content: If you‚Äôre interested in Compose and Google Maps, Chris Arriola wrote about the lessons learned while building Maps Compose. You‚Äôll see how they took advantage of Kotlin features, how to aim for binary compatibility, subcomposition, and more!

newsresources.title: I/O 22: What's New in Android
newsresources.content: For a survey of what I/O 22 offers to Android developers in video form check out the What‚Äôs New in Android talk.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: What's New for Android Devs
newsresources.content: Move quickly through some of the top material for Android Devs at IO/22

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Android Fireside Chat
newsresources.content: Android Fireside Chat is back! Android leaders answered your questions from the stage.

newsresources.title: 13 Things to know for Android developers at Google I/O!
newsresources.content: There aren‚Äôt many platforms where you can build something and instantly reach billions of people around the world, not only on their phones‚Äîbut their TVs, cars, tablets, watches, and more. Today, at Google I/O, we covered a number of ways Android helps you make the most of this opportunity, and how Modern Android Development brings as much commonality as possible, to make it faster and easier for you to create experiences that tailor to all the different screens we use in our daily lives.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Now in Android, the App ‚è±Ô∏è
newsresources.content:
After being available on this blog, our YouTube series, and a podcast, starting today, you can check out the alpha version of the Now in Android app on GitHub that was featured in the Google I/O 2022 Developer Keynote üéâ

The app showcases best practices, opinionated designs, and solutions to complex real-world problems.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Jetpack, Compose, and Tooling üöÄ
newsresources.content: What‚Äôs new in Jetpack covered additions and updates to the over 120 libraries we‚Äôve created to address common pain points and make development easier.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Lazy layouts in Compose
newsresources.content: Compose brings a simple and performant way of creating scrolling lists, with fewer lines of code than RecyclerView. Learn how lazy layouts enable adding content on demand, how to use Lazy composables, how these work under the hood, and optimization tips for better performance.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Fragments: The good (non-deprecated) parts
newsresources.content: Fragments have been in constant motion over the past couple of years as we move towards a world where all the behavior is defined. Some of these moves have resulted in new APIs designed to do a specific function and replace old, unreliable ones. Learn about the changes in menus, fragment communication, the new strict mode, single lifecycle, and more.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Performance best practices for Jetpack Compose
newsresources.content: Jetpack Compose can feel like magic, but what do you do when the magic isn't as performant as you want? Discover best practices in Jetpack Compose with regards to performance, common mistakes, and how to avoid them.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Workshop: Basic layouts in Compose
newsresources.content: Learn how to implement a realistic and complex UI using Compose Layouts.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Workshop: State in Jetpack Compose
newsresources.content: Discover the core concepts of using state in Jetpack Compose by building a wellness app. Learn how the app's state determines what is displayed in the UI, how Compose keeps the UI updated when state changes, how to optimize the structure of your composable functions, and work with ViewModels in a Compose app.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Airbnb uses Jetpack Compose to empower devs to do their best work
newsresources.content: Jetpack Compose, Android‚Äôs modern UI-building toolkit, directly supports both of Airbnb‚Äôs development principles. Compose provided a solid foundation for adaptable, quality engineering and reduced boilerplate code, so developers could focus on delivering a great user experience ‚Äî and advance their two-fold pursuit of engineering excellence.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: What‚Äôs new in Android development tools
newsresources.content: Get an overview of what's new in Android Studio for Android app developers, including demos and a presentation of relevant features that can accelerate developers' workflow on the latest Android APIs.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Designing apps for large screens
newsresources.content: Explore key concepts and strategies for adapting mobile apps to large screen devices, such as tablets and foldables. Dig into the challenges of optimizing design and finding ways to meet the changing expectations of your users, in order to offer the highest quality large screen app experience.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Learn how to update your app for the larger screen
newsresources.content: You already have an app you‚Äôve been working on for years, with a set, and hard to change, architecture. Discover the many options to bring your existing app forward, and build optimized large screen experiences without starting from scratch.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Implementing Android apps for all screen sizes
newsresources.content: Get a better understanding of how to build your app to fill all screen formats. Explore development best practices to optimize applications for all devices with an emphasis on Jetpack Compose, navigation, managing state, and testing.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Input for all screens
newsresources.content: Learn about some straight-forward best practices to support input methods like keyboard, mouse, and stylus. These simple changes can elevate your app experience and grow user engagement.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Building an adaptive layout with SlidingPaneLayout
newsresources.content: Learn how to add a list and detail layout to a View-based app with SlidingPaneLayout. Explore how to reconfigure your fragments, open and close the detail pane, handle custom back navigation, and disable gesture navigation.

newsresources.title: I/O 22: Android Developer Story: eBay gets a 4.7 Google Play rating
newsresources.content: Matthew Mossman, Android engineer for eBay, shares how he and his team optimized the eBay app for large screens and discusses the impact they saw in their customer‚Äôs engagement and experience on the tablets.
